response:
The probability of rolling a number greater than 3 on a fair six‑sided die is

\[
P(\text{>3})=\frac{3}{6}=0.5=50\%.
\]

The probability of rolling two even numbers in a row is

\[
P(\text{even, even})=\left(\frac{3}{6}\right)^2=0.25=25\%.
\]

To find how much more likely the first event is compared to the second, compute the percent increase relative to the second probability:

\[
\frac{P(\text{>3})-P(\text{even, even})}{P(\text{even, even})}\times100\%
   =\frac{0.5-0.25}{0.25}\times100\%
   =1\times100\%
   =100\%.
\]

So the event “roll a number > 3” is **100 % more likely** than “roll two even numbers in a row**.

#### 100
